- Developers are pretty generous with event rewards, i only spent 20-30 dollars in 8 months of playing the game and have 80% of all characters (could've been more if my luck wasn't so bad, ha).
- The game isn't so difficult and you don't need to have a lot of characters with maxxed dupes to clear endgame content, unless you want to seriously compete in leaderboards. Feel free to pull for whoever you like the most. I've heard plenty of horror stories from HSR players about powercreep and very unforgiving endgame without whaling in gacha, rest assured you won't have that here.
- Since this is a sequel, the story and lore are much more developed compared to other gacha games. I highly suggest to play GFL1 or at least read it's story through the wiki if it's not your cup of tea. The protagonist - Commander, is not a blank slate, has a distinc personality and there are no pointless "dialog options", which are always just 1)yes and 2)yes, but in other words (looking at you Genshin and WuWa). - OST composed by Vanguard Studios. If you know, you know. Superb work as always.
[h3]Cons:[/h3]
- The easy difficulty i mentioned earlier is also a negative. Developers took inspiration from XCOM 2 when designing gameplay, but not enough of the tactical aspect made it's way here.
- Somewhat questionable management decisions. MICA is a bit infamous for their occasional incompetence, but they conduct surveys on a monthly basis and staff members relay suggestions to the developers made by players in the official discord server.
I admit, i'm having trouble naming more cons and you can call me biased in that regard, but i really want you to give this game a chance. No game is perfect of course, but the fact that GFL1 and PNC are still up and running even almost a decade later is proof of their dedication and passion.
[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
Solid sci-fi novel that sometimes suffers from being a gacha game. Nevertheless, it has a great potential and the setting makes it stand out among it's competitors. I shall stick around and continue to report on what this game has to offer.

What is Grass? More Than Just the Green Under Your Feet
Grass is a ubiquitous and remarkably diverse group of plants that blankets vast stretches of our planet, from manicured lawns and sprawling savannas to the cereal crops that feed a significant portion of the world's population. Belonging to the Poaceae family, one of the largest and most economically important plant families, grasses are characterized by their relatively simple structure, yet they play a crucial and multifaceted role in both natural ecosystems and human civilization.

At its core, grass is a monocotyledonous plant, meaning it begins its life with a single seed leaf. Its structure is elegantly efficient for its primary functions of growth and resilience. Key features include fibrous root systems that anchor the plant and absorb water and nutrients, hollow, jointed stems called culms, and long, narrow leaves with parallel veins that grow from the base of the plant. This basal growth is a key adaptation that allows grasses to withstand grazing and mowing without being destroyed.

The diversity within the grass family is staggering, with over 12,000 identified species. This includes the familiar turf grasses that create our lawns and sports fields, the towering bamboo that can form dense forests, and the essential cereal grains such as wheat, rice, corn (maize), barley, and oats. These grains form the cornerstone of global food systems, providing a substantial portion of the calories consumed by humans and livestock.

Ecologically, grasses are indispensable. They are the dominant vegetation in many ecosystems, most notably grasslands, savannas, and prairies, which cover approximately 20% of the Earth's land surface. These ecosystems support a vast array of wildlife, from grazing herbivores like bison and antelope to the predators that depend on them. The extensive root systems of grasses also play a vital role in preventing soil erosion by binding the soil together. Furthermore, through the process of photosynthesis, grasses are significant producers of oxygen and play a crucial part in the global carbon cycle.

The economic importance of grasses extends far beyond their role as a food source. They are used for:

Animal Fodder: Hay and silage, derived from grasses, are essential feed for livestock.

Biofuels: Certain grasses, like switchgrass and sugarcane, are being increasingly utilized for the production of ethanol.

Construction: Bamboo is a versatile and sustainable building material used in everything from scaffolding to flooring.

Recreation and Aesthetics: Grasses are cultivated for lawns, parks, and sports fields, providing surfaces for a wide range of activities and enhancing the beauty of our landscapes.

Other Uses: Grasses are also used in the production of paper, thatch for roofing, and even in some traditional medicines.

In essence, grass is a foundational element of our planet's biosphere. Its unassuming appearance belies a remarkable resilience, diversity, and importance that have shaped landscapes, supported civilizations, and continue to be a vital resource for both the natural world and human society.

While I still enjoy the first game, Exilium simply isn’t to my liking. I’ve played more hours than I’d like to admit, but honestly, it’s not a good game in my opinion.

I eagerly awaited Exilium’s release and played it for a while before realizing all its flaws.

To begin with, the story feels so weak. The main characters have little relevance, and the plot progresses far too slowly. People argue that the original also took time to develop, but two years after its release we already had Deep Dive and Singularity. Now, many story points lead nowhere, and it’s disappointing how the dark tone of the first game shifted to something forgettable.

The gameplay, while not perfect in the original either, feels even more repetitive and dull here. At least the first game experimented with different objectives and allowed decisions that led to alternate endings (Continuum Turbulence). Even the pvp is unbalanced, with the same doll teams in every match.

As for the gacha system, the original is far superior to this one. Resources were easy to obtain, and production results were actually rewarding. Exilium uses the Genshin gacha, where you must grind or pay for collapse pieces on each banner to get what you want and have greater efficiency. You won't get much by playing as f2p. You need to pull duplicates for skills, and even the oath now requires payment unlike the original, which allowed you to get it with gems, which the game frequently gave you but weren't necessary for natural progress either.

Fanservice isn’t inherently bad, but here it’s excessive. The constant focus on character attributes, exaggerated jiggle, and foot fetish make it feel annoying. The original also had fanservice skins, yes, but they were 2D skins, much lighter and more irrelevant. It’s annoying to see well developed and impactful characters like 416 or RO, characters who went through a conspiracy, terrorism, a machine rebellion, and had personality problems, now reduced to prostitute skins and jiggle.

If you’re interested in this game, just skip it and try the original instead. Given how the original story ended, I expected something far better from its sequel. If you still enjoy Exilium that’s fine, but it's definitely not a good sequel.

While I still enjoy the first game, Exilium simply isn’t to my liking. I’ve played more hours than I’d like to admit, but honestly, it’s not a good game in my opinion.

I eagerly awaited Exilium’s release and played it for a while before realizing all its flaws.

To begin with, the story feels so weak. The main characters have little relevance, and the plot progresses far too slowly. People argue that the original also took time to develop, but two years after its release we already had Deep Dive and Singularity. Now, many story points lead nowhere, and it’s disappointing how the dark tone of the first game shifted to something forgettable.

The gameplay, while not perfect in the original either, feels even more repetitive and dull here. At least the first game experimented with different objectives and allowed decisions that led to alternate endings (Continuum Turbulence). Even the pvp is unbalanced, with the same doll teams in every match.

As for the gacha system, the original is far superior to this one. Resources were easy to obtain, and production results were actually rewarding. Exilium uses the Genshin gacha, where you must grind or pay for collapse pieces on each banner to get what you want and have greater efficiency. You won't get much by playing as f2p. You need to pull duplicates for skills, and even the oath now requires payment unlike the original, which allowed you to get it with gems, which the game frequently gave you but weren't necessary for natural progress either.

Fanservice isn’t inherently bad, but here it’s excessive. The constant focus on character attributes, exaggerated jiggle, and foot fetish make it feel annoying. The original also had fanservice skins, yes, but they were 2D skins, much lighter and more irrelevant. It’s annoying to see well developed and impactful characters like 416 or RO, characters who went through a conspiracy, terrorism, a machine rebellion, and had personality problems, now reduced to prostitute skins and jiggle.

If you’re interested in this game, just skip it and try the original instead. Given how the original story ended, I expected something far better from its sequel. If you still enjoy Exilium that’s fine, but it's definitely not a good sequel.

While I still enjoy the first game, Exilium simply isn’t to my liking. I’ve played more hours than I’d like to admit, but honestly, it’s not a good game in my opinion.

I eagerly awaited Exilium’s release and played it for a while before realizing all its flaws.

To begin with, the story feels so weak. The main characters have little relevance, and the plot progresses far too slowly. People argue that the original also took time to develop, but two years after its release we already had Deep Dive and Singularity. Now, many story points lead nowhere, and it’s disappointing how the dark tone of the first game shifted to something forgettable.

The gameplay, while not perfect in the original either, feels even more repetitive and dull here. At least the first game experimented with different objectives and allowed decisions that led to alternate endings (Continuum Turbulence). Even the pvp is unbalanced, with the same doll teams in every match.

As for the gacha system, the original is far superior to this one. Resources were easy to obtain, and production results were actually rewarding. Exilium uses the Genshin gacha, where you must grind or pay for collapse pieces on each banner to get what you want and have greater efficiency. You won't get much by playing as f2p. You need to pull duplicates for skills, and even the oath now requires payment unlike the original, which allowed you to get it with gems, which the game frequently gave you but weren't necessary for natural progress either.

Fanservice isn’t inherently bad, but here it’s excessive. The constant focus on character attributes, exaggerated jiggle, and foot fetish make it feel annoying. The original also had fanservice skins, yes, but they were 2D skins, much lighter and more irrelevant. It’s annoying to see well developed and impactful characters like 416 or RO, characters who went through a conspiracy, terrorism, a machine rebellion, and had personality problems, now reduced to prostitute skins and jiggle.

If you’re interested in this game, just skip it and try the original instead. Given how the original story ended, I expected something far better from its sequel. If you still enjoy Exilium that’s fine, but it's definitely not a good sequel.
